title: One dead in commuter plane crash on Alaskan island
text:
CLOSE A PenAir plane carrying a high school swim team crashed near a small Alaska community. USA TODAY

One person is dead after a plane went off a landing runway on Thursday in a small Alaska town near the Bering Sea called Unalaska, one of the nation's busiest fishing ports.

Alaska State Troopers identified the victim of the crash as 38-year-old David Allan Oltman of Washington state.

As for the remaining passengers, 11 were brought to a local clinic with injuries ranging from minor to critical, according to a statement from the city of Unalaska. Seven of the patients arrived in an ambulance and four came in personal vehicles; one was to medevaced to Anchorage, the city said.

Just before 11 a.m. on Friday, the Unalaska/Dutch Harbor Airport remained closed, Meadow Bailey, communications director at the Alaska Department of Transportation & Public Facilities, told USA TODAY.

"National Transportation Safety Board and Federal Aviation Administration accident investigators are responding," Bailey said earlier in an email.

NTSB sending team of 9 to Unalaska, AK to investigate Oct. 17, 2019, accident involving Peninsula Air #3296, Saab SB20, that overran runway on landing. More information will be released when available. — NTSB_Newsroom (@NTSB_Newsroom) October 18, 2019

"One of the NTSB investigators from the Alaska office is on the ground to secure the scene, but the full investigative team is not expected to arrive until tomorrow," said Keith Holloway, NTSB public affairs officer.

Around 5:40 p.m. on Thursday, a SAAB-Scania 2000 operated by Peninsula Airways, also called PenAir, went off the end of the runway under unknown circumstances, Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Allen Kenitzer said in an email to The Associated Press. All 39 passengers and crew members were accounted for, the City of Unalaska said in a release.

A high school swim team was on the aircraft. A school official said the swim team was fine and eating pizza shortly after the incident. .

“At present, all students and chaperones are accounted for and are OK, albeit a bit shaken up,” said the statement by Cordova Superintendent Alex Russin.

Russin said he spoke with Unalaska City School District Superintendent John P. Conwell, who assured him the students were safe.

A commuter airplane carrying 42 people, including a high school swim team, went off the runway while landing at the airport in Unalaska, Alaska, Thursday, Oct. 17, 2019. (Photo: Jim Paulin, AP)

PenAir, which is owned by Ravn Air Group, said it’s fully cooperating with the NTSB and has established a family assistance line.

An eyewitness said the flight from Anchorage to Dutch Harbor landed about 500 feet beyond the airport, near the water. Social media posts show the plane’s nose hanging over a rock embankment, but not in the water.

CLOSE Airplane wings are not always in the middle of the plane. USA TODAY

The plane appeared to have been forced beyond its planned landing area by high winds the community has been experiencing recently, freelance photographer Jim Paulin, who witnessed the crash, told The Associated Press.

SOURCE maps4news.com/©HERE (Photo: USA TODAY)

Unalaska is about 825 miles west of Anchorage.

Contributing: The Associated Press; David Oliver, USA TODAY

Read or Share this story: https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/airline-news/2019/10/18/penair-plane-carrying-high-school-swim-team-crashes-alaska-island/4020418002/
description: A commuter airplane carrying 42 people went off the runway while landing Thursday, killing one.
